content.title: Fasciotomy
content.definition: Fasciotomy is the surgical release of fascial compartments to relieve elevated intracompartmental pressure in compartment syndrome, preventing irreversible muscle and nerve ischemia.

indications.ischemia_reperfusion: Prophylactic after prolonged limb ischemia (>4-6 hours)
indications.trauma: Crush injury, fractures, bleeding into compartment

compartment_syndrome.pathophysiology: Elevated pressure reduces capillary perfusion → ischemia → edema → further pressure increase
compartment_syndrome.timeline: Irreversible muscle damage occurs within 4-6 hours

clinical_diagnosis.earliest_sign: Pain out of proportion to injury, pain with passive stretch
clinical_diagnosis.note: Pulses may be preserved despite compartment syndrome

anterior.muscles: Tibialis anterior, EHL, EDL, peroneus tertius
anterior.clinical: Foot drop, first web space sensory loss

lateral.clinical: Weak eversion, dorsal foot sensory loss

superficial_posterior.clinical: Weak plantarflexion, lateral foot sensory loss

deep_posterior.clinical: Weak toe flexion, plantar sensory loss

lower_leg_four_compartment.two_incision: Medial and lateral skin incisions (standard approach)

surgical_technique.forearm: Volar incision for volar compartment, dorsal for dorsal compartment

wound_management.leave_open: Never close primarily - risk of recurrence
wound_management.dressings: Negative pressure wound therapy (VAC) often helpful
wound_management.skin_grafting: May be needed if cannot close primarily

prophylactic_fasciotomy.timing: At time of revascularization, before closure

learning_objectives: Recognize clinical signs of compartment syndrome
Identify the four compartments of the lower leg
Outline surgical approach to lower leg fasciotomy
clinical_pearls: Pain out of proportion and pain with passive stretch are earliest signs
Pulses may be present despite compartment syndrome
Irreversible muscle damage occurs within 4-6 hours
Two-incision technique releases all four lower leg compartments
